title: Tiny shrimp-like creature found living in whale shark's mouth uses long hairy legs to catch its food
text:
A tiny, shrimp-like creature that used its long, hairy legs to catch food has been found living in an unlikely home — the mouth of a whale shark.

The little residents — dubbed Podocerus jinbe — are a type of gammaridea, a group of species known to live in environments from high up mountains to the deep sea.

Gammaridea are in turn a type of crustacean, a group that includes water fleas.

Lead researcher and biologist Ko Tomikawa of Japan's Hiroshima University said that he was 'surprised' to find a species of gammaridea living in another animal's mouth.

Scroll down for video

WHAT IS PODOCERUS JINBE? Podocerus jinbe is a tiny crustacean of the sub-order gammaridea. It has a brown-coloured body and reach around five millimetres in length. It captures food using its hairy legs. The new species takes it name after the Japanese for whale shark, whose gills it calls home. Living in the shark's mouth provides fresh water, food and safety.

'This creature — which is usually 3–5 centimetres long — is amazing, because they can live in so many different kinds of environment,' Professor Tomikawa told the AFP.

'But I didn't expect we would find one inside the mouth of a whale shark.'

The new species has a brown-coloured body that reaches around five millimetres in length and has hairy legs that help it catch organic substances to eat.

There are many good reasons why the newly-discovered species might choose such an unexpected environment to call home, Professor Tomikawa explained.

'The mouth of the whale shark is probably a good habitat because fresh seawater, which is necessary for them to breath, comes in regularly.'

'Food flows in too — and it also provides a safe place without any predators.'

'The mouth of the whale shark is probably a good habitat because fresh seawater, which is necessary for them to breath, comes in regularly,' said Professor Tomikawa. Pictured, a whale shark feeding near the ocean's surface (stock image)

The tiny crustacean has been named in honour of its whale shark hosts — which are known as 'jinbe zame' in Japanese.

The new species was discovered by the staff of an an aquarium in southern Okinawa prefecture, who reached out to Professor Tomikawa for help identifying the creatures they had found living in one of their whale sharks.

Around a thousand Podocerus jinbe were found inside the gills of that shark's mouth, Professor Tomikawa said.
